intro: Grammitis jungermannioides, commonly known as the creeping liverwort, is a non-vascular plant belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit and is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors or rock crevices. The plant has small, closely arranged leaves that are often spirally arranged along the stems. It reproduces via spores, which are produced in cup-like structures called sporangia located on the undersides of the leaves. Grammitis jungermannioides plays an important ecological role in nutrient cycling and soil stabilization in its habitat.
